Posts.Content: sophie786 wrote: I was dx. with invasive ductal carcinoma on jan. 30, 2012.  I am undergoing chemotherapy before surgery.  The tumor was around 5 cm and there is a second lesion/tumor around the nipple area. I just had my third dose of chemo yesterday.  I'm 40 yrs old with no family history, Brca tests came back negative.   For those of you that had chemo before surgery what was your experience like and did you have total of 6 cycles before surgery and then surgery.  HOw long did you wait for surgery after chemo ended? did you choose lumpectomy, unilateral mascectomy, or bilateral masectomy? I am ER & PR negative and HerNeu positive (3+). I want to choose the best option for best possible outcome and to lower chance of recurrence.  My oncologist wants to go for masectomy and wait for a few years for reconstruction.  I am debating whether i should go for radical modified mascetomy (from my understanding it is locally advanced as per pet scan but no other metasis other than suspious for lymph node metasis).  Brain mri was clear and pet scan showed the same thing. I have 4 kids (17, 15, 13 with autism, and 6 year old).  My kids need me....I loved my breasts and i general I was great shape...everyone would always say that I did not look like the mom of a 17 year old...) but at this point I desparately want to see my kids grow up and whatever will help me achieve that is my goal with god's help and mercy. Dx 1/30/2013, IDC, Left, 4cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 5/22 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Chemotherapy 2/4/2013 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Taxol (paclitaxel) Dx 10/28/2014, Stage IV, Grade 3 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Neo-Adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy before surgery and radiation) sophie786 sophie786

Posts.Content: sophie786 wrote: how does one decide which way to go?  I'm 40 with no family history of BC.  I tested negative for BRCA genes.  I have bc in left breast.  It is probably stage 3.  I initially wanted to remove both breaast but now am finding out that reconstruction is not a walk in the park.  In my case BS is not recommending immediate reconstuction and are recommending not implants bc of the risk of failing as I need radiation in additon to having masectomy.  I will going on herceptin. How do people go about deciding?  are posts devoted to that.  I have decide soon bc hopefully my surgery will early june. Dx 1/30/2013, IDC, Left, 4cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 5/22 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Chemotherapy 2/4/2013 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Taxol (paclitaxel) Dx 10/28/2014, Stage IV, Grade 3 Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2015 06:50AM sophie786 wrote: hAVE ANY of you ladies had luck with MO at MSKCC? could you pm which MO you have. they all do the same thing in the same hospital but BED SIDE MANNER and aLOT compassion are even more lethal on cancer than chemo. working with a compatible MO makes alot of difference. We are fighting the battles of life so you want one who is compassionate but who knows their stuff and is cutting edge.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2015 10:02AM sophie786 wrote: actually my tumor markers have been in the teens (this cancer isn't producing excess tumor markers). that's why my first MO couldn't catch the mets. and a year ago they found widespread mets on a followup appt (where i went for a clean bill of health). i had a pretty bad cold they day i went for ct scan. the pet wasn't bad but MO says they say branching on CT scan. so confused. I thought kadcyla was working. Now she wants switch to gemzar. I'm frustrated bc i was tolerating kadcyla quite well and all levels are excellent. i need brain radiation bc they found 22 sub centimeter lesions in the brain. so there are 2 trials. one is with soranfib and WBR and other one is immunotherapy and WBR. I'm really sad that i can't continue on kadcyla.

Posts.Content: sophie786 wrote: Hi are there any ladies who are being treated at Memorial Sloan kettering Cancer Center (Main Campus)?  I had my surgery with Lisa Scalfani and radiation at msk.  I had a MO who was not affiliated with MSK and now wish to transfer all of my care to MSK.  I just feel its easier to treated and followed by one system rather than being at several different place.s any any reccommend a really good MO that they have been happy with.  I am looking for someone who listens to patients rather talks down to them.  I want to be an active member of my care. If there is already a group please point me in the right direction. Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2015 09:08PM sophie786 wrote: they may be considering tykerb and xeloda to help improve brain mets and systemic disease. my MO was pushing for WBR but i believe the Rad Onc feels that we can wait and see if something else improves the brain mets.
Posts.Title: anyone with er/pr negative and Her2 positive metastatic cancer sophie786 sophie786

Posts.Content: sophie786 wrote: Hi.  could somebody recommend a really good, caring thorough medical oncologist in the New York New Jersey or Pennsylvania Area.  I had my surgery at MSK (main campus) and radiation (long island) there as well.  My experience has been decent. My oncologist is non-sloan affiliated and a friend of the family.  I didn't have too much too time to shop around because i had an agressive tumor and it is growing pretty rapidly.  I want to start chemo asap.  I had chemo first, surgery, then radiation.  while my MO is good I don't like the idea of going to someone who is a family friend.  I would like somebody objective, thorough and is not condescending who is into integretive care.  I have been reading online reviews and I see mixed reviews.  Some people love their experience and others have had a horrible experience there.  Looking for really thorough medical oncologist who is has expertise in hormone negative cancer and for whom you are not just a case but a real person with a desire to beat this disease.   Please give your honest feedback about Memorial Sloan, and recommendations for a really good medical oncologist. Dx 1/30/2013, IDC, Left, 4cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 5/22 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Chemotherapy 2/4/2013 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Taxol (paclitaxel) Dx 10/28/2014, Stage IV, Grade 3 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: how is your experience with memorial sloan kettering (MSK) sophie786 sophie786

Posts.Content: May 10, 2013 04:08PM sophie786 wrote: Whats the standard amount of radiation necessary?  I was told during chemo that I would be needing radiation even after a mascetomy bc of chest well infilitration.  of course the breast cancer is on left side.  a RO (family acquaintance) mentioned the IRMT technique.  I've been reading about ABC technique. I am wondering how much radiation I would need?  I was told 5 or 6 weeks.  Another RO told me she likes to do 7 weeks which I figure might be 33 and actually 6.5 weeks.  It really stinks this whole breast cancer.esp for a person who was otherwise healty.  I hate to take any medication and chemo has been really rough.  kind of upsetting since my daughter is graudating from HS later this month and I've been away from my family (kids ,1715,13) so I could be with family.  at the end of the day I want to do everything to avoid recurrence and be able to tell my kids that I did everything in my control.  The risks are horrible....even worse for left side breast cancer patients but what choice do we really have?  You don't want to regret not doing everything possible.  I pray to god for minimal damage and side effects....but we are all well aware that the risks are very very real.
